docs.title: Structured Logs in .NET
docs.text:
with regular string interpolation, if you want to find all the logs where AccountId == 244 you have to hope the logs are in a very specific format and you need to search for ('accountid: 244', 'account id = 244', 'accountid = 244' etc...).

With structured logs it breaks out those variables into a structured system that recognizes those variables (like {AccountId}) and extracts them into an easily filterable format.

For example:

In the RCMBackgroundService there is a log: _logger.LogInformation("Excecuting {ClassName}", className);

You can find any log, logged with the Variable ClassName like this: 

traces
| where customDimensions.OriginalFormat == "{ClassName}"
And specific ones like this: 
traces
| where customDimensions.ClassName == "TaskUpdateNotificationService"

docs.title: Morning Dash
docs.text: Morning Dash is your day at a glance. See local weather, your commute, and calendar events all in one place.

docs.title: Siddur
docs.text: A Jewish Prayer app with over 35K MAU - displays relevant prayers based on location, date and time.

docs.title: Tidy Albatross
docs.text: An endless runner game where users help an Albatross clean a beach.

docs.title: WebHunt
docs.text: Web Hunt, is a single page web application inspired by Product Hunt. It allows creators to share their products and receive feedback from developers and tech enthusiasts.
